texts.shortText: Small, plump wader with straight, black bill. Non-breeding birds mostly pale (hence the species name alba, meaning white) except mottled grey wings and tail and marked dark shoulder patch. Head with darker cap, band through eye and band across back of neck. Underside white. Eyes dark brown, legs and feet black. Breeding birds much darker.
Total length 20-21 cm, wingspan 43 cm, mass 55-60 g.

Global: Breeds in the high Arctic of North America, Asia and Europe. Summer migrant to coastal areas across the world.

Local/Regional: Along coast across whole region, but most common on west coast, especially Namibia.

Arrives in South Africa from breeding grounds in Siberia and Greenland in about September and leaves again in May. Primarily found in small groups on beaches, less often on rocky shores, often running rapidly ahead of the waves and probing for small invertebrates. May use ‘stitching’ technique, which leaves characteristic pattern zig-zag lines of holes in sand. Roosts above the high-water mark, often communally with other waders.

On west coast beaches with kelp wrack takes mostly beach hoppers (talitrid amphipods) and kelp fly larvae. On beaches without wrack consumes burrowing amphipods and isopods, polychaete worms, white mussels (sometimes just their siphons) and mysids shrimps. On rocky shores may also take small bivalves, insect larvae and juvenile klipfish.

Does not breed in South Africa, but only in northern latitudes. Solitary nester, the nest is a shallow scrape on the ground, often lined with lichen or dry leaves. Eggs 2-4, laid in June and July, greenish with small brown markings. Incubation by both parents, duration 24-32 days, young fledge after 17 days. Often two clutches raised in the breeding season.
Can be confused with Little or Red-necked stints, but these are much smaller (12-16 cm).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 348).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 364).
